articles.headline: Bipartisan Plan for Budget Deal Buoys President
articles.snippet: A group of senators made a new push to win backing for an ambitious deficit-reduction proposal that includes new revenues and deep spending cuts.
articles.abstract: A group of senators made a new push to win backing for an ambitious deficit-reduction proposal that includes new revenues and deep spending cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama seized on the re-emergence of an ambitious bipartisan budget plan in the Senate on Tuesday to invigorate his push for a big debt-reduction deal, and he summoned Congressional leaders back to the bargaining table this week to “start talking turkey.”
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Google Looks for the Next Google
articles.snippet: Google is playing venture capitalist in the hottest market for technology start-up companies in over a decade.
articles.abstract: Google is playing venture capitalist in the hottest market for technology start-up companies in over a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google thinks it can be young and crazy again. And it is betting $200 million that it is right.

articles.headline: Strong Sales Help Extend Apple Streak
articles.snippet: Strong sales in emerging markets and to business customers helped Apple extend its streak of stellar performance in the last quarter without introducing any major new products.
articles.abstract: Strong sales in emerging markets and to business customers helped Apple extend its streak of stellar performance in the last quarter without introducing any major new products.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Strong sales to shoppers in emerging markets and to business customers helped Apple extend its lengthy streak of stellar performance in its earnings report on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Military Plotted to Tilt U.S. Policy, F.B.I. Says
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s military has spent millions in a covert effort to tilt American policy against India’s control of Kashmir, including funneling campaign donations, the F.B.I. has claimed.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s military has spent millions in a covert effort to tilt American policy against India’s control of Kashmir, including funneling campaign donations, the F.B.I. has claimed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pakistan’s military, including its powerful spy agency, has spent $4 million over two decades in a covert attempt to tilt American policy against India’s control of much of Kashmir — including funneling campaign donations to members of Congress and presidential candidates, the F.B.I. claimed in court papers unsealed Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: In Scarred Syria City, a Vision of a Life Free From Dictators
articles.snippet: In the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad, Hama represents the competing visions of the protesters and the government: liberation or chaos.
articles.abstract: In the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad, Hama represents the competing visions of the protesters and the government: liberation or chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMA, Syria — In this city that bears the scars of one of the modern Middle East’s bloodiest episodes, the revolt against President Bashar al-Assad has begun to help Syrians imagine life after dictatorship as it forges new leaders, organizes its own defense and reckons with a grim past in an uncertain experiment that showcases the forces that could end Mr. Assad’s rule.

articles.headline: Utah Liquor Laws, as Mixed Up as Some Drinks
articles.snippet: The ever-changing liquor laws in Utah reflect a continuing balancing act between the interests of the Mormon Church and those of the hospitality industry.
articles.abstract: The ever-changing liquor laws in Utah reflect a continuing balancing act between the interests of the Mormon Church and those of the hospitality industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DRAPER, Utah — When Vuz Restaurant and Vuda Bar opened here a couple of months ago, the idea was to bring a dash of dining chic to this corner of the Salt Lake Valley.

articles.headline: Negotiating Election Headwinds
articles.snippet: With the economy struggling, the Obama campaign is looking at past campaigns for clues on how to avoid losing.
articles.abstract: With the economy struggling, the Obama campaign is looking at past campaigns for clues on how to avoid losing.

articles.headline: Scandal Stirs U.S. Debate on Big Media
articles.snippet: The British phone-hacking affair that has enveloped the News Corporation has emboldened American advocacy groups who believe that media companies have become too big and powerful.
articles.abstract: The British phone-hacking affair that has enveloped the News Corporation has emboldened American advocacy groups who believe that media companies have become too big and powerful.
articles.lead_paragraph: Progressive activists and public interest groups have long blasted Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation for political biases. But in recent weeks they have seized on a new and more tangible reason to call for the revocation of his TV licenses and the breakup of his company: the British hacking scandal.

articles.headline: U.S. to Close 800 Computer Data Centers
articles.snippet: Analysts estimate that thousands of jobs will be eliminated with the federal government’s plan to shut 40 percent of its computer centers over the next four years.
articles.abstract: Analysts estimate that thousands of jobs will be eliminated with the federal government’s plan to shut 40 percent of its computer centers over the next four years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government plans to shut 40 percent of its computer centers over the next four years to reduce its hefty technology budget and modernize the way it uses computers to manage data and provide services to citizens.

articles.headline: Countrywide to Distribute Settlement to Its Clients
articles.snippet: Countrywide Home Loans agreed to pay borrowers $108 million for charging excessive fees when they fell behind on their mortgages.
articles.abstract: Countrywide Home Loans agreed to pay borrowers $108 million for charging excessive fees when they fell behind on their mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 450,000 borrowers who were charged excessive fees by Countrywide Home Loans when they fell behind on their mortgages will finally begin receiving the $108 million the company agreed to pay in a settlement struck with the Federal Trade Commission in June 2010, the agency said Wednesday.
